title: Circua Seminars (Collaborative International Research Centre for Universal Access)
abstractText:
Our focus is on Universal Access in the inclusive Information Society - a vitally important, multidisciplinary subject. Emerging information society technologies (IST) are very powerful, supporting a wide range of functions. As such, the main question to ask is not “What can this technology do?” but “What can users do with this technology?” A key issue is accessibility. Universal access for all is defined as access for all, irrespective of technology, location, ability, disability or social membership. However, this requires a substantial, multidisciplinary effort, including psychology, statistics, computing, education, sociology, engineering, policy makers, designers and IST vendors.

The seminar series is co-ordinated by the Collaborative International Research Centre for Universal Access (CIRCUA), and aims to tackle the problems of accessibility in general, including e-accessibility in particular, by drawing together new and existing researchers, policy makers and practitioners. The workshops have four themes:

  • User diversity, modelling and profiling;
  • User sensitive design and methods;
  • Design standards & legislation for accessibility; and
  • Essential practitioner skills.

Planned outcomes include: the identification of solutions to accessibility problems; a multi-author publication; and the creation of partnerships for further research and application.
